item.title: Solutions to Exercise 9 and Exercise 15 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give solutions to Exercise 9 and Exercise 15 of Terence Tao's post 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 Exercise 9 (Recursive description of a generated Boolean algebra) Let $latex {{{\mathcal F}}}&fg=000000$ be a collection of sets in a set $latex {{X}}&fg=000000$. Define the sets $latex {{{\mathcal F}_0, {\mathcal F}_1, {\mathcal F}_2, \ldots}}&fg=000000$ recursively as follows:
  • $latex {{{\mathcal F}_0 := {\mathcal F}}}&fg=000000$.
  • For each $latex {{n \geq 1}}&fg=000000$, we define $latex {{{\mathcal F}_n}}&fg=000000$ to be the collection of all sets that either the union of a finite number of sets in $latex {{{\mathcal F}_{n-1}}}&fg=000000$ (including the empty union $latex {{\emptyset}}&fg=000000$), or the complement of such a union.
Show that $latex {{\langle {\mathcal F} \rangle_{\hbox{bool}} = \bigcup_{n=0}^\infty {\mathcal F}_n}}&fg=000000$.
Proof: First we show that $latex {\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$ is a boolean algebra.
  • It is easy to verify that $latex {\emptyset\in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$(including the empty union).
  • If $latex {A,B\in \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$,there must exist $latex {N,M\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}&fg=000000$ such that $latex {A\in \mathcal{F}_N}&fg=000000$,$latex {B\in \mathcal{F}_M}&fg=000000$.Without loss of generality,let $latex {N\geq M}&fg=000000$,then it is easy to verify that $latex {B\in \mathcal{F}_N}&fg=000000$.Then it can be verified that $latex {X\backslash A,X\backslash B\in \mathcal{F}_{N+1}}&fg=000000$,$latex {A\bigcup B\in\mathcal{F}_{N+1}}&fg=000000$.So $latex {X\backslash A,A\bigcup B\in\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$.
Then it is easy to verify that $latex {\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$ is the smallest boolean algebra that contain $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$(Because any boolean algebra contain $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$ generate $latex {\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{F}_n}&fg=000000$). $latex \Box&fg=000000$
Exercise 2 Exercise 15 (Recursive description of a generated $latex {{\sigma}}&fg=000000$-algebra) (This exercise requires familiarity with the theory of ordinals, which is reviewed here. Recall that we are assuming the axiom of choice throughout this course.) Let $latex {{{\mathcal F}}}&fg=000000$ be a collection of sets in a set $latex {{X}}&fg=000000$, and let $latex {{\omega_1}}&fg=000000$ be the first uncountable ordinal. Define the sets $latex {{{\mathcal F}_\alpha}}&fg=000000$ for every countable ordinal $latex {{\alpha \in \omega_1}}&fg=000000$ via transfinite induction as follows:
  • $latex {{{\mathcal F}_\alpha := {\mathcal F}}}&fg=000000$.
  • For each countable successor ordinal $latex {{\alpha = \beta+1}}&fg=000000$, we define $latex {{{\mathcal F}_\alpha}}&fg=000000$ to be the collection of all sets that either the union of an at most countable number of sets in $latex {{{\mathcal F}_{n-1}}}&fg=000000$ (including the empty union $latex {{\emptyset}}&fg=000000$), or the complement of such a union.
  • For each countable limit ordinal $latex {{\alpha = \sup_{\beta < \alpha} \beta}}&fg=000000$, we define $latex {{{\mathcal F}_\alpha := \bigcup_{\beta < \alpha} {\mathcal F}_\beta}}&fg=000000$.
Show that $latex {{\langle {\mathcal F} \rangle = \bigcup_{\alpha \in \omega_1} {\mathcal F}_\alpha}}&fg=000000$.
Proof:
  • $latex {\emptyset\in\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$(including the empty union $latex {\emptyset}&fg=000000$.)
  • Let's see a countable sequence of sets $latex {A_1,\cdots,A_n,\cdots}&fg=000000$,where $latex {\forall i\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}&fg=000000$,$latex {A_i\in\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$.It is easy to verify that $latex {\bigcup_{i\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}A_i\in\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$.And that $latex {X\backslash A_i\in\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$.
Then it is easy to verify that $latex {\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$ is the smallest boolean algebra that contain $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$(Because any boolean algebra contain $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$ generate $latex {\bigcup_{\alpha\in\omega_1}\mathcal{F}_{\alpha}}&fg=000000$). $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: Solution to Exercise 16 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give solution to Exercise 16 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 Exercise 16 (This exercise requires familiarity with the theory of cardinals.) Let $latex {{{\mathcal F}}}&fg=000000$ be an infinite family of subsets of $latex {{X}}&fg=000000$ of cardinality $latex {{\kappa}}&fg=000000$ (thus $latex {{\kappa}}&fg=000000$ is an infinite cardinal). Show that $latex {{\langle {\mathcal F} \rangle}}&fg=000000$ has cardinality at most $latex {{\kappa^{\aleph_0}}}&fg=000000$. (Hint: use Exercise 15.) In particular, show that the Borel $latex {{\sigma}}&fg=000000$-algebra $latex {{{\mathcal B}[{\bf R}^d]}}&fg=000000$ has cardinality at most $latex {{c := 2^{\aleph_0}}}&fg=000000$. Conclude that there exist Jordan measurable (and hence Lebesgue measurable) subsets of $latex {{{\bf R}^d}}&fg=000000$ which are not Borel measurable. (Hint: How many subsets of the Cantor set are there?) Use this to place the Borel $latex {{\sigma}}&fg=000000$-algebra on the diagram that you drew for Exercise 6.
Lemma 1 If $latex {X}&fg=000000$ is an infinite set,then

$latex \displaystyle X\times \{0,1\}\equiv X. &fg=000000$

Proof of this lemma is omitted,a detailed proof can be found in A course on Borel sets by S.M. Srivastava ,theorem 1.4.3.Now we prove that $latex {\langle \mathcal{F}\rangle}&fg=000000$ has cardinality at most $latex {\kappa^{\aleph_0}}&fg=000000$. Proof: $latex {\kappa^{\aleph_0}}&fg=000000$ is the cardinality of the set $latex {\{f|f:\mathbf{N}\rightarrow \mathcal{F}\}}&fg=000000$.For sake of convenience,let's assume that there is no element in $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$ which is the at most countable union of other elements of $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$(except $latex {\emptyset}&fg=000000$).Let's consider the at most countable union of the elements of $latex {\mathcal{F}}&fg=000000$,all such at most countable union form a set $latex {A}&fg=000000$.It is easy to verify that there is an injection from $latex {A}&fg=000000$ to $latex {\{f|f:\mathbf{N}\rightarrow \mathcal{F}\}}&fg=000000$.So the cardinality of $latex {A}&fg=000000$ is less or equal to the cardinality of $latex {\{f|f:\mathbf{N}\rightarrow\mathcal{F}\}}&fg=000000$.According to lemma (1),we have

$latex \displaystyle A\equiv \langle \mathcal{F}\rangle. &fg=000000$

So there exists an injection from $latex {\langle \mathcal{F}\rangle}&fg=000000$ to $latex {\{f|f:\mathbf{N}\rightarrow\mathcal{F}\}}&fg=000000$,which means that the cardinality of $latex {\langle \mathcal{F}\rangle}&fg=000000$ is less or equal to $latex {\kappa^{\aleph_0}}&fg=000000$. $latex \Box&fg=000000$ And it is easy to prove that Borel $latex {{\sigma}}&fg=000000$-algebra $latex {{{\mathcal B}[{\bf R}^d]}}&fg=000000$ has cardinality at most $latex {{c := 2^{\aleph_0}}}&fg=000000$.

item.title: Solution to Exercise 28.6 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give solution to Exercise 28.6 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 (Exercise 28.6) If $latex {{f_n: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}&fg=000000$ are a sequence of measurable functions that converge pointwise to a limit $latex {{f: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}&fg=000000$, then show that $latex {{f}}&fg=000000$ is also measurable. Obtain the same claim if $latex {{[0,+\infty]}}&fg=000000$ is replaced by $latex {{{\bf C}}}&fg=000000$.
Proof: $latex {f}&fg=000000$ is pointwise approximated by $latex {f_n}&fg=000000$,this means that for any given positive integer $latex {m}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex \displaystyle \bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{P}}\{x:|f_n(x)-f(x)|< \frac{1}{m}\}=X. &fg=000000$

Where $latex {P}&fg=000000$ is an infinite subset of $latex {\mathbf{N}^{+}}&fg=000000$,such that $latex {\forall k>l,k,l\in\mathbf{P}}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex \displaystyle \{x:|f_k(x)-f(x)|< \frac{1}{m}\}\supseteq \{x:|f_l(x)-f(x)|<\frac{1}{m}\}. &fg=000000$

Equivalently,

$latex \displaystyle \bigcap_{m\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}\bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{P}}\{x:|f_n(x)-f(x)|< \frac{1}{m}\}=X. &fg=000000$

Now we prove that for any given non-negative real number $latex {\lambda}&fg=000000$,$latex {\{x:f(x)>\lambda\}}&fg=000000$ is a measurable set in $latex {X}&fg=000000$.We denote the set $latex {\{x:f(x)>\lambda\}}&fg=000000$ as $latex {A}&fg=000000$.Suppose the restriction of the function $latex {f}&fg=000000$ on $latex {A}&fg=000000$ is $latex {g}&fg=000000$,and the restriction of the function $latex {f_n}&fg=000000$ on $latex {A}&fg=000000$ is $latex {g_n}&fg=000000$.It is easy to verify that $latex {g}&fg=000000$ is pointwise approximated by $latex {g_n}&fg=000000$,and $latex {\forall x\in X,g(x)>\lambda}&fg=000000$.So we have

$latex \displaystyle \{x:f(x)>\lambda\}=\bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{P}}\left\{x:g_n(x)>\lambda\right\}. &fg=000000$

So $latex {\{x:f(x)>\lambda\}}&fg=000000$ is measurable. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give solution to Exercise 28.8 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 (Exercise 28.8) Show that the sum or product of two measurable functions in $latex {{[0,+\infty]}}&fg=000000$ or $latex {{{\bf C}}}&fg=000000$ is still measurable.
Proof: Let $latex {f,g}&fg=000000$ be two measurable functions.Now let's prove that $latex {f+g}&fg=000000$ is measurable.Let $latex {A}&fg=000000$ be an open set in $latex {[0,+\infty]}&fg=000000$,it is enough for us to prove that $latex {(f+g)^{-1}(A)}&fg=000000$ is a measurable set in $latex {X}&fg=000000$.$latex {A}&fg=000000$ can be expressed into the sum of two intersected open sets $latex {A_f,A_g}&fg=000000$ in $latex {[0,+\infty]}&fg=000000$,i.e,$latex {\forall x\in A}&fg=000000$,$latex {x=x_f+x_g}&fg=000000$,where $latex {x_f\in A_f,x_g\in A_g}&fg=000000$,$latex {A_f\bigcap A_g\neq\emptyset}&fg=000000$,and $latex {\forall x>y}&fg=000000$,we have $latex {x_f>y_f}&fg=000000$,$latex {x_g>y_g}&fg=000000$.And $latex {f^{-1}(A_f),f^{-1}(A_g)}&fg=000000$ is non-empty.So there is a order preserving bijection between the sets $latex {A}&fg=000000$ and $latex {A_f}&fg=000000$,$latex {A}&fg=000000$ and $latex {A_g}&fg=000000$.Let $latex {m\in A}&fg=000000$,$latex {f^{-1}(A_f)\bigcap g^{-1}(A_g)}&fg=000000$ is measurable,and $latex {(f+g)^{-1}(m)\in f^{-1}(A_f)\bigcap g^{-1}(A_g)}&fg=000000$. $latex \Box&fg=000000$ Similarly,in order to prove that $latex {fg}&fg=000000$ is measurable,we need only to prove that $latex {f^2}&fg=000000$ is measurable,because $latex {4fg=(f+g)^2-(f-g)^2}&fg=000000$.In order to prove that $latex {f^2}&fg=000000$ is measurable,we only need to consider the special case when $latex {f}&fg=000000$ is an unsigned measurable function,because any function can be decomposed into the addition of two unsigned measurable functions,i.e,for any function $latex {f}&fg=000000$,$latex {f}&fg=000000$ can be represented uniquely as $latex {f_1+f_2}&fg=000000$,where $latex {f_1}&fg=000000$ is non-negative measurable function and $latex {f_2}&fg=000000$ is non-positive measurable function,and if $latex {f_1(x)+f_2(x)=0}&fg=000000$,then $latex {f_1(x)=f_2(x)=0}&fg=000000$ ,if $latex {f_1(x)+f_2(x)}&fg=000000$ is positive,then $latex {f_2(x)=0}&fg=000000$,if $latex {f_1(x)+f_2(x)}&fg=000000$ is negative,then $latex {f_1(x)=0}&fg=000000$.So in order to prove that $latex {f^2}&fg=000000$ is measurable,we only need to prove that $latex {f_1^2+f_2^2+2f_1f_2}&fg=000000$ is measurable. We first prove that $latex {f_1^2}&fg=000000$ is measurable.For any open set $latex {A}&fg=000000$ in $latex {[0,+\infty]}&fg=000000$,let we consider the open set $latex {\sqrt{A}=\{\sqrt{x}:x\in A\}}&fg=000000$.$latex {f_{1}^{-1}(\sqrt{A})}&fg=000000$ is measurable,so $latex {(f^2)^{-1}(A)}&fg=000000$ is measurable.Similary,$latex {f_2^2}&fg=000000$ is measurable.Now we prove that $latex {f_1f_2}&fg=000000$ is measurable,this is simple,because $latex {f_1f_2=0}&fg=000000$.

item.title: A proof of Egorov's theorem
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give a proof of Egorov's theorem stated in Exercise 30 of Terence Tao's post 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 Exercise 30 (Egorov’s theorem) Let $latex {{{{{(X,{\mathcal B},\mu)}}}}}&fg=000000$ be a finite measure space (so $latex {{{{{\mu(X) < \infty}}}}}&fg=000000$), and let $latex {{{{{f_n: X \rightarrow {\bf C}}}}}}&fg=000000$ be a sequence of measurable functions that converge pointwise almost everywhere to a limit $latex {{{{{f: X \rightarrow {\bf C}}}}}}&fg=000000$, and let $latex {{{{{\epsilon > 0}}}}}&fg=000000$. Show that there exists a measurable set $latex {{{{{E}}}}}&fg=000000$ of measure at most $latex {{{{{\epsilon}}}}}&fg=000000$ such that $latex {{{{{f_n}}}}}&fg=000000$ converges uniformly to $latex {{{{{f}}}}}&fg=000000$ outside of $latex {{{{{E}}}}}&fg=000000$. Give an example to show that the claim can fail when the measure $latex {{{{{\mu}}}}}&fg=000000$ is not finite.
Proof: $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ is pointwise approximated by $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$,this means that,$latex {{{{\forall \epsilon>0}}}}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{N}^+}\left\{x:|f(x)-f_n(x)|<\epsilon\right\}=X. \ \ \ \ \ (1)}}}}}&fg=000000$

  It is clear that $latex {{{{\bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}\{x:|f(x)-f_n(x)|<\epsilon\}}}}}&fg=000000$ is measurable for each $latex {{{{\epsilon}}}}&fg=000000$.According to the monotone convergence theorem,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\mu\left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{N}\{x:|f(x)-f_n(x)|<\epsilon\}\right)=\left(\bigcup_{n\in\mathbf{N}^+}\left\{x:|f(x)-f_n(x)|<\epsilon\right\}\right)=\mu(X). \ \ \ \ \ (2)}}}}}&fg=000000$

  Translating equation 2 into English,we have the conclusion that $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ can be uniformly approximated by $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ on $latex {{{{X\backslash E}}}}&fg=000000$,where $latex {{{{E}}}}&fg=000000$ is a measurable set whose measure is very small.Note that in the process of translation,the condition that $latex {{{{\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ has finite is required. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: A function is measurable if and only if it can be pointwise approximated by simple functions
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
Definition 1 (Simple function) An (unsigned) simple function $latex {{{{f: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$ on a measurable space $latex {{{{(X,{\mathcal B})}}}}&fg=000000$ is a measurable function that takes on finitely many values $latex {{{{a_1,\ldots,a_k}}}}&fg=000000$.
Theorem 2 Let $latex {{{{(X, {\mathcal B}, \mu)}}}}&fg=000000$ be a measure space,$latex {{{{f: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$ is measurable if and only if $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ can be pointwise approximated by a sequence of simple functions.
Proof: $latex {{{{\Leftarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$This is proved in the post Solution to Exercise 28.6 of 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems. $latex {{{{\Rightarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$For each $latex {{{{x\in \{f(x):x\in X\}}}}}&fg=000000$,we construct an open interval $latex {{{{(x-\frac{\varepsilon}{n},x+\frac{\varepsilon}{n})}}}}&fg=000000$,thus according to the Lindelof's lemma,$latex {{{{\{f(x):x\in X\}}}}}&fg=000000$ can be covered by at most countable numbers of intervals of length $latex {{{{\frac{2\varepsilon}{n}}}}}&fg=000000$.For each open interval $latex {{{{(x-\frac{\varepsilon}{n},x+\frac{\varepsilon}{n})}}}}&fg=000000$,we know that

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \{x\in X:f(x)\in (x-\frac{\varepsilon}{n},x+\frac{\varepsilon}{n})\} }}}}}&fg=000000$

is a measurable set in $latex {{{{X}}}}&fg=000000$,a function supported by such a set which takes constant value on $latex {{{{x}}}}&fg=000000$ is a simple function.As $latex {{{{n\rightarrow \infty}}}}&fg=000000$,it is easy to verify that all such simple function converges pointwise to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: A proof of Fatou's lemma
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I give a proof of Fatou's lemma which is the Corollary 16 of Terence Tao's post 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Theorem 1 Corollary 16 (Fatou’s lemma) Let $latex {{{{(X,{\mathcal B},\mu)}}}}&fg=000000$ be a measure space, and let $latex {{{{f_1,f_2,\ldots: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$ be a sequence of unsigned measurable functions. Then

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X \liminf_{n \rightarrow \infty} f_n\ d\mu \leq \liminf_{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_X f_n\ d\mu.}}}}}&fg=000000$

Proof: According to the monotonicity property,for all $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X\inf f_nd\mu\leq \int_Xf_nd\mu, }}}}}&fg=000000$

so

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X\inf f_nd\mu\leq \inf\int_Xf_nd\mu. }}}}}&fg=000000$

According to $latex {{{{\inf\int_Xf_nd\mu\leq\liminf_{n\rightarrow\infty}f_nd\mu}}}}&fg=000000$,we thus have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X\inf f_nd\mu\leq\liminf_{n\rightarrow\infty}\int_Xf_nd\mu. }}}}}&fg=000000$

Based on the above inequality,we make some further improvement.It is clear that

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X\inf f_nd\mu\leq \liminf_{n\rightarrow\infty}\int_Xf_nd\mu,n\geq m,\mbox{where}~m~\mbox{is any given positive integer.} }}}}}&fg=ff0000$

Thus

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X\liminf_{n\rightarrow\infty}f_nd\mu\leq \liminf_{n\rightarrow\infty}\int_Xf_nd\mu\mbox{(Note that this requires the upward monotone convergence theorem,why?)}. }}}}}&fg=000000$

$latex \Box&fg=000000$
Remark:Fatou's lemma has a conterpart called reverse Fatou's lemma. Theorem  (Reverse Fatou’s lemma) Let $latex {{{{(X,{\mathcal B},\mu)}}}}&fg=000000$ be a measure space, and let $latex {{{{f_1,f_2,\ldots: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$ be a sequence of unsigned measurable functions,and for all $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ is bounded by an absolutely integrable function $latex {{{{g:X\rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$. Then

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_X \limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} f_n\ d\mu \geq \limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} \int_X f_n\ d\mu.}}}}}&fg=000000$

Proof: The proof makes use of the downwards monotone convergence theorem,so the condition "for all $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ is bounded by an absolutely integrable function $latex {{{{g:X\rightarrow [0,+\infty]}}}}&fg=000000$." is necessary. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

In this post I give solution to Exercise 49 of Terence Tao's post 245A, Notes 3: Integration on abstract measure spaces, and the convergence theorems.
Exercise 1 Exercise 49 Let $latex {{{{(X, \mathcal{B}, \mu)}}}}&fg=000000$ be a finite measure space (i.e. $latex {{{{\mu(X) < \infty}}}}&fg=000000$), and let $latex {{{{f: X \rightarrow \mathbf{R}}}}}&fg=000000$ be a bounded function. Suppose that $latex {{{{\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ is complete, which means that every sub-null set is a null set. Suppose that the upper integral

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \overline{\int}_X f\ d\mu := \inf_{g \geq f; g \hbox{ simple}} \int_X g\ d\mu }}}}}&fg=000000$

and lower integral

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \underline{\int}_X f\ d\mu := \sup_{h \leq f; h \hbox{ simple}} \int_X h\ d\mu }}}}}&fg=000000$

agree. Show that $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ is measurable. (This is a converse to Exercise 11 of Notes 2.)
Proof: We just need to prove that $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ can be pointwise approximated by a sequence of simple functions.Then according to A function is measurable if and only if it can be pointwise approximated by simple functions,we can prove the measurability of $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.Note that the condition $latex {{{{\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ is complete is necessary in order to assure that when we ignore a subnull set the measurability of $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ is not affected. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: Solution to Exercise 5 of 245A, Notes 4: Modes of convergence
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
Exercise 5 (Fast $latex {{{{L^1}}}}&fg=000000$ convergence) Suppose that $latex {{{{f_n, f: X \rightarrow {\bf C}}}}}&fg=000000$ are measurable functions such that$latex {{{{\sum_{n=1}^\infty \|f_n-f\|_{L^1(\mu)} < \infty}}}}&fg=000000$; thus,not only do the quantities $latex {{{{\|f_n-f\|_{L^1(\mu)}}}}}&fg=000000$ go to zero (which would mean $latex {{{{L^1}}}}&fg=000000$ convergence), but they converge in an absolutely summable fashion. Show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges pointwise almost everywhere to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.Show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges almost uniformly to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.
  Proof: First we show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges pointwise almost everywhere to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.If $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ do not convergence pointwise almost everywhere to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$,this means that $latex {{{{\exists \varepsilon_{1}>0}}}}&fg=000000$,such that for all $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \mu\left(\left\{x\in X:|f_{n}(x)-f(x)|\geq\varepsilon_1\right\}\right)>0. }}}}}&fg=000000$

This contradicts the fact that the quantities $latex {{{{\|f_n-f\|_{L^1(\mu)}}}}}&fg=000000$ go to zero as $latex {{{{n\rightarrow\infty}}}}&fg=000000$ and they converge in an absolutely summable fashion. Now we prove that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges almost uniformly to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.According to Egrove's theorem,we just need to prove that for any given positive real number $latex {{{{\varepsilon}}}}&fg=000000$ and any given $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle X\backslash \{x\in X:|f_n(x)-f(x)|\leq\varepsilon\}~\mbox{has finite measure}. }}}}}&fg=000000$

This is easy(Otherwise,this will contradict the fact that the quantities $latex {{{{\|f_n-f\|_{L^1(\mu)}}}}}&fg=000000$ go to zero as $latex {{{{n\rightarrow\infty}}}}&fg=000000$ and they converge in an absolutely summable fashion.).Done. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: Proof of Theorem 5 of 245A, Notes 4: Modes of convergence
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
In this post I prove theorem 5 of 245A, Notes 4: Modes of convergence.
Exercise 1 (Theorem 1.5.13) (Uniformly integrable convergence in measure). Let $latex {{{{f_{n} : X \rightarrow \mathbf{C}}}}}&fg=000000$ be a uniformly integrable sequence of functions, and let $latex {{{{f : X \rightarrow C}}}}&fg=000000$ be another function. Then $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in $latex {{{{L_1}}}}&fg=000000$ norm to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ if and only if $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ in measure.
Proof: $latex {{{{\Rightarrow}}}}&fg=000000$:This can be easily verified by contradiction. $latex {{{{\Leftarrow}}}}&fg=000000$:$latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ is a uniformly integrable sequence of functions,so according to Exercise 11,for every $latex {{{{\epsilon > 0}}}}&fg=000000$ there exists a $latex {{{{\delta > 0}}}}&fg=000000$ such that

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_E |f_n|\ d\mu \leq \epsilon.\ \ \ \ \ (1)}}}}}&fg=000000$

whenever $latex {{{{n \geq 1}}}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {{{{E}}}}&fg=000000$ is a measurable set with $latex {{{{\mu(E) \leq \delta}}}}&fg=000000$. $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in measure to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$,so for any given positive real number $latex {{{{\varepsilon}}}}&fg=000000$ ,there exists a positive integer $latex {{{{N}}}}&fg=000000$ such that for all $latex {{{{n\geq N}}}}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \mu\left(\{x\in X:|f(x)-f_n(x)|\geq\varepsilon\}\right)\leq \delta. }}}}}&fg=000000$

So according to equation 1,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \int_{\{x\in X:|f(x)-f_n(x)|\geq\varepsilon\}}|f_n|d\mu\leq\epsilon. \ \ \ \ \ (2)}}}}}&fg=000000$

$latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ is a uniformly integrable sequence of functions,so we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \sup_{n}\int_{|f(x)|\leq\gamma}|f_n(x)|d\mu\rightarrow 0~~\mbox{as}~~\gamma\rightarrow 0. \ \ \ \ \ (3)}}}}}&fg=000000$

$latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in measure to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$,so we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\mu(\{x\in X:|f_n(x)-f(x)|\geq \frac{\gamma}{2}\})=0. \ \ \ \ \ (4)}}}}}&fg=000000$

Combine equations 2,3,4 we can get the conclusion. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

In this post I give solution to Exercise 15 of 245a-notes-4-modes-of-convergence.
Exercise 14 (Defect version of Fatou’s lemma) Suppose that $latex {{{{f_n: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty)}}}}&fg=000000$ are measurable, are such that $latex {{{{\sup_n \int_X f_n\ d\mu < \infty}}}}&fg=000000$, and converge pointwise almost everywhere to some measurable limit $latex {{{{f: X \rightarrow [0,+\infty)}}}}&fg=000000$. Show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in $latex {{{{L^1}}}}&fg=000000$ norm to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ if and only if $latex {{{{\int_X f_n\ d\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ converges to $latex {{{{\int_X f\ d\mu}}}}&fg=000000$. Informally, we see that in the unsigned, bounded mass case, pointwise convergence implies $latex {{{{L^1}}}}&fg=000000$ norm convergence if and only if there is no loss of mass.
Proof: $latex {{{{\Rightarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$ The proof is easy.The essential point is to prove that $latex {{{{\int_Xfd\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ is finite.In order to prove it,the condition $latex {{{{\sup_n \int_X f_n\ d\mu < \infty}}}}&fg=000000$ is essential. $latex {{{{\Leftarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$ Simple. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

Exercise 1 Exercise 16 Suppose that $latex {{{{f_n: X \rightarrow {\bf C}}}}}&fg=000000$ are a dominated sequence of measurable functions, and let $latex {{{{f: X \rightarrow {\bf C}}}}}&fg=000000$ be another measurable function. Show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges pointwise almost everywhere to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ if and only if $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in almost uniformly to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.
Proof:
Lemma 1 Because $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ are dominated and convergence pointwise to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$,so according to the dominated convergence theorem,

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\int_Xf_n(x)d\mu=\int_Xfd\mu. }}}}}&fg=000000$

So $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in $latex {{{{L_1}}}}&fg=000000$ norm to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$(Why?hint:use the fact that $latex {{{{\int_Xfd\mu}}}}&fg=000000$ is finite).
According to Egrove's theorem,we just need to prove that for any given $latex {{{{\varepsilon>0}}}}&fg=000000$ and any given positive integer $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,we have

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \mu(X\backslash\{x\in X:|f_n(x)-f(x)|\leq\varepsilon,n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}\})\mbox{is finite.} }}}}}&fg=000000$

Let's prove by contradiction.Otherwise,there exists $latex {{{{\epsilon>0}}}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {{{{n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,such that

$latex {{{{{\displaystyle \mu(X\backslash\{x\in X:|f_n(x)-f(x)|\leq\epsilon,n\in\mathbf{N}^{+}\})\mbox{is infinite.} }}}}}&fg=000000$

However,this contradicts the above lemma. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: Solution to Exercise 18 of 245a:modes of convergence
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
Exercise 1 Exercise 18 Let $latex {{{{X}}}}&fg=000000$ be a finite measure space. Given any real-valued measurable function $latex f: X \rightarrow \mathbf{R}&fg=000000$, we define the cumulative distribution function $latex {{{{F: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow [0,1]}}}}&fg=000000$ of $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ to be the function $latex {{{{F(\lambda) := \mu( \{x \in X: f(x) \leq \lambda \} )}}}}&fg=000000$. Given another sequence $latex {{{{f_n: X \rightarrow \mathbf{R}}}}}&fg=000000$ of real-valued measurable functions, we say that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in distribution to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ if the cumulative distribution function $latex {{{{F_n(\lambda)}}}}&fg=000000$ of $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges pointwise to the cumulative distribution function $latex {{{{F(\lambda)}}}}&fg=000000$ of $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ at all $latex {{{{\lambda \in \mathbf{R}}}}}&fg=000000$ for which $latex {{{{F}}}}&fg=000000$ is continuous. Show that if $latex {{{{f_{n}}}}}&fg=000000$ converges to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ pointwise or in measure, then it converges in distribution to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.
Proof: First,I prove that if $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges pointwise to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$,then it converges in distribution to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.In order to prove it,the condition $latex {{{{X}}}}&fg=000000$ has finite measure is essential because with this condition we can use Egrove's theorem to show that $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges almost uniformly to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ on $latex {{{{X}}}}&fg=000000$,then combine with the condition "$latex {{{{F}}}}&fg=000000$ is continuous" we can prove that pointwise convergence implies convergence in distribution. Now I prove that if $latex {{{{f_n}}}}&fg=000000$ converges in measure to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$ then it converges in distribution to $latex {{{{f}}}}&fg=000000$.This is a simple corollary of Exercise 17. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

item.title: Covering a non-closed interval by disjoint closed intervals
item.dc:creator: h5411167
item.content:encoded:
Exercise 1 Is it possible to express the non-closed interval $latex {{{{[0,1)}}}}&fg=000000$ as a countable union of disjoint closed intervals,i.e,whether $latex {{{{[0,1)=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i}}}}&fg=000000$,where $latex {{{{\forall i\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{A_i=[a_i,b_i],a_i\leq b_i}}}}&fg=000000$,and $latex {{{{\forall i\neq j}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{A_i\bigcap A_j=\emptyset}}}}&fg=000000$.
The answer is NO.The essential of this exercise is to use the fact that Cantor-like set are  uncountable. Now I give a wrong proof,the red words is where I am wrong.We first prove a lemma.
Lemma 1 $latex {{{{[0,1)}}}}&fg=000000$ can be expressed as a countable union of disjoint closed intervals if and only if $latex {{{{[0,1]}}}}&fg=000000$ can be expressed as a countable union of disjoint closed intervals.
Proof: $latex {{{{\Rightarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$If $latex {{{{[0,1)=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i}}}}&fg=000000$,where $latex {{{{\forall i\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{A_i=[a_i,b_i],a_i\leq b_i}}}}&fg=000000$.And $latex {{{{\forall i\neq j}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{A_i\bigcap A_j=\emptyset}}}}&fg=000000$,then $latex {{{{[0,1]=(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i)\bigcup [1,1]}}}}&fg=000000$.Done. $latex {{{{\Leftarrow:}}}}&fg=000000$If $latex {{{{[0,1]=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}B_i}}}}&fg=000000$,where $latex {{{{\forall i\in\mathbf{N}^{+}}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{B_i=[c_i,d_i],c_i\leq d_i}}}}&fg=000000$.And $latex {{{{\forall i\neq j}}}}&fg=000000$,$latex {{{{B_i\bigcap B_j=\emptyset}}}}&fg=000000$,then there must exists $latex {{{{B_k}}}}&fg=000000$ such that $latex {{{{1\in B_k}}}}&fg=000000$.Now we consider $latex {{{{(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}B_i)\backslash B_k}}}}&fg=000000$,let $latex {{{{(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}B_i)\backslash B_k=[0,a)}}}}&fg=000000$,where $latex {{{{0< a\leq 1}}}}&fg=000000$.So $latex {{{{[0,a)}}}}&fg=000000$ can be expressed as a countable union of disjoint closed intervals,by multiplying a constant $latex {{{{\frac{1}{a}}}}}&fg=000000$,we can get that $latex {{{{[0,1)}}}}&fg=000000$ can be expressed as a countable union of disjoint closed intervals. $latex \Box&fg=000000$ According to the above lemma,we just need to prove that $latex {{{{[0,1]}}}}&fg=000000$ can not be expressed as a countable union of closed intervals.We prove by contradiction,if the answer is yes,then it is clear(Why?) that there exists a sequence of monotone increasing points $latex {{{{a_1,a_2,\cdots,a_n,\cdots}}}}&fg=000000$ such that each item $latex {{{{a_p}}}}&fg=000000$ of this sequence is exactly the internal point of a unique closed intervals $latex {{{{I_p}}}}&fg=000000$ of positive length.This sequence of points must converges to a point $latex {{{{a_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ in $latex {{{{[0,1]}}}}&fg=000000$. If $latex {{{{a_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ is also the internal point of a closed interval $latex {{{{I_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$,then it does no harm to turn the sequence of intervals $latex {{{{I_1,I_2,\cdots,I_n,\cdots,I_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ into a sequence of open intervals $latex {{{{L_1,L_2,\cdots,L_n,\cdots,L_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ by removing the boundary points of each interval.We know that this sequence of open intervals covers the closed set $latex {{{{\{a_1,\cdots,a_n,\cdots,a_{\lim}\}}}}}&fg=000000$.According to the finite covering theorem,there must exists finite number of open intervals that also covers the closed set $latex {{{{\{a_1,\cdots,a_n,\cdots,a_{\lim}\}}}}}&fg=000000$,which is a contradiction(Why?) If $latex {{{{a_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ is the boundary point of a closed interval,then transform this sequence of closed intervals continuously to make some closed interval longer and make some other intervals shorter to make $latex {{{{a_{\lim}}}}}&fg=000000$ and all the points of the sequence lies at the internal of each interval while still keeps the property that the union of all these intervals is $latex {{{{[0,1]}}}}&fg=000000$.In this way,we transform this case into the above case.
